title: Welcome
text: Welcome to the BST623 R Programming resource page! This site provides a collection of functions commonly used in the BST623 class, making it easier for you to access and utilize R programming tools in your coursework. Whether you’re a seasoned programmer or new to R, this page is designed to provide a comprehensive and user-friendly experience. Happy coding!

title: About
text: BST623 Software Tools for Manuscript Development and Reproducible Research is a course at the University of Miami, offered by the Biostatistics program. This class is taught by professor, Dr. Raymond Balise. The course focus on the use of software tools for creating professional-quality manuscripts and conducting reproducible research. Whether you’re an experienced researcher or just starting out, BST 623 will provide valuable skills and knowledge to use R for your research.

title: BST623 functions
text:
library()
[library]{.blue}(*package*){.center}


What it does

The library library() function loads a package into working memory (from long term storage on your hard disk drive or solid state drive).



Demo code
```{r eval=FALSE}   library(survial)    ```  


Usefull stuff
+ There are a few "meta" packages, like `tidymodels` and `tidyverse`, which load many packages from a single .blue[`library()`] function call.  ??? stats::filter and dplyr::filter --- 


Common Problems
NA # Related Functions NA

title: BST623 functions
text:
dplyr::pull()
[pull]{.blue}(*dataset*, *variable*){.center}


What it does

The pull() is used to copy of a variable out of a dataset into a new object.



Demo code
```{r eval=FALSE}   pull(mtcars, mpg)   ```  


Usefull stuff
+ When it is used with the .blue[`filter()`] function, .blue[`pull()`] can be used to extract a single value from a dataset. This is useful when you need to extract a number,  like an odds ratio or a *p*-value, for a report.    + .blue[`pull()`] is the only .blue[`dplyr`] function that does not return a `tibble`.  --- 


Common Problems
NA # Related Functions NA

title: BST623 functions
text:
class()
[class]{.blue}(_thingy_){.center}


What it does
If you are not sure what something is, you can check its class by typing using the class() function in the console windowpane.


Demo code
```{r eval=FALSE}   class(iris) ```  


Usefull stuff
.pull-left[.center[![:scale 100%](images/class1.jpg)]]  .pull-right[.center[![:scale 100%](images/class2.jpg)]] --- 


Common Problems
NA # Related Functions NA

title: BST623 functions
text:
%>% from the magrittr Package
 $thing_1$ [%>%]{.blue}      $thing_2$  {.center}


What it does

The symbol %>% is called a pipe. When describing a workflow, it is spoken as “then”.
It normally sends the output from \(thing_1\) to the first argument of \(thing_2\).



Demo code
```{r eval=FALSE}   mtcars %>%    filter(mpg == 30.4)   ```  


Usefull stuff
+ Many functions can be connected in a pipeline.    + Start code after a pipe on a new line.    + Indent all lines of code two spaces after the first pipe. --- 


Common Problems
NA # Related Functions NA

title: BST623 functions
text:
dplyr::filter()
{.center}


What it does
.center[filter(tableName, logical test)] + Use filter() to pick rows/records. Inside the () you put a logic check. filter() keeps rows/records where the logic check is true.


Demo code
```{r, eval=FALSE}  filter(mtcars, am == 0)  # cars with automatic transmission filter(mtcars, is.na(mpg))  # cars missing miles per gallon information filter(mtcars, !is.na(mpg))  # cars not missing miles per gallon information    ``` --- 


Usefull stuff
NA # Common Problems NA # Related Functions NA

title: BST623 functions
text:
suppressPackageStartupMessages()
[suppressPackageStartupMessages]{.blue}(library(*package*)){.center}


What it does

Load a package without printing its greeting message.



Demo code
```{r eval=FALSE}   suppressPackageStartupMessages(library(tidyverse))  ```  


Usefull stuff
+ This is very useful with the .blue[`tidyverse`] and .blue[`tidymodels`].  Use this if and only if you are also using the .blue[`conflicted`] package (to avoid function name conflicts).  --- 


Common Problems
NA # Related Functions NA

title: BST623 functions
text:
rm()
[rm]{.blue}(*things*){.center}


What it does
The rm() function removes an object from R’s working memory.


Demo code
```{r eval=FALSE}   life_the_universe_and_everything <- 42  rm(life_the_universe_and_everything)    ``` --- 


Usefull stuff
NA # Common Problems NA # Related Functions NA

title: BST623 functions
text:
remotes::install_cran()
[remotes::install\_cran]{.blue}("*thingy*"){.center}


What it does

A better way to add packages is to use the install_cran() function from the remotes package.



Demo code
```{r, eval=FALSE}  remotes::install_cran("DOPE")   ``` Paste that line into the Console windowpane (bottom left corner) and tap the return or enter key on your keyboard.   


Usefull stuff
+ It will check to see the package has been updated before it bothers to do the download.   ---
